title: for loop expression type reported after IntoIterator

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

labels.name: D-confusing
labels.description: Confusing diagnostic error that should be reworked

labels.name: D-incorrect
labels.description: A diagnostic that is giving misleading or incorrect information

body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.

If you cannot produce a minimal reproduction case (something that would work in
isolation), please provide the steps or even link to a repository that causes
the problematic output to occur. 
-->

Given the following code: <!-- Please provide a link to play.rust-lang.org -->

```rust
fn make() -> Result<Vec<(usize, char)>, std::io::Error> {
    Ok(vec![(42, 'f')])
}

fn main() -> Result<(), std::io::Error> {
    for (i,j) in make() {
        println!("{} {}", i, j);
    }
    Ok(())
}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0308]: mismatched types
 --> src/main.rs:6:9
  |
6 |     for (i,j) in make() {
  |         ^^^^^    ------ this expression has type `Vec<(usize, char)>`
  |         |
  |         expected struct `Vec`, found tuple
  |
  = note: expected struct `Vec<(usize, char)>`
              found tuple `(_, _)`
```

This is seriously misleading.  The expression `make()` in fact has type `Result<Vec<..>>`.  If it had the type `Vec<(usize, char)>` as the error message claims, the code would be correct.

The bug in the program is a missing `?`.

I think the diagnostics bug is in the reporting the type of `Item` after the `for`-induced `IntoIterator` call as if it were the type of the iterator.

Perhaps something like this would be better:

```
6 |     for (i,j) in make() {
  |         ^^^^^    ------ this iterator yields `Item`s of type `Vec<(usize, char)>`
  |         |
  |         expected struct `Vec`, found `Item` of type tuple
```

That would at least be true, although it would still be a bit obtuse.  (We have the common problem of "expected" vs "found" being backwards, which really doesn't help.)

Better, if possible, would be something mentioning the fact that `Result` is being treated as the iterator for `for`, which is probably not what the user intended.  Similarly for `Option` I guess, as regards diagnostics,.

`for .. in Result<..>` is a bit of a footgun because as well as producing a confusing type situation, it throws away the error if there was one.

https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=nightly&mode=debug&edition=2018&gist=9cdf69fd508fd36973bd1e1c7313cbd3
